awd_titl_txt: The Reactivity of Green Rust Towards Redox-Stable Trace Metals in Reducing Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
This award from the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Division of Chemistry supports Professor Evert Elzinga and his students to study green rust (GR). GR is an iron-hydroxide mineral that forms in certain natural and engineered environments such soils along river banks, aquifers, drinking water lines, and barriers used for groundwater remediation. These minerals are very reactive and are known to degrade both organic and inorganic pollutants through reduction/oxidation (redox) reactions. Little is known about the reactions involved. The goal of this project is to study the chemical reactivity of GR with a series of environmentally relevant trace metals. The work aims to improve knowledge of the mobility of metal pollutants in reducing environments and provide basic insights into the surface chemistry of green rust minerals. The project provides scientific training for graduate students. Underrepresented minority undergraduate students from the Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program at Rutgers-Newark are involved in the research.

Trace metals of different sizes and valences (Mn(II), Ni(II), Zn(II), Cd(II), Pb(II) and Cr(III)) are reacted with GR in pre-equilibrated anoxic suspensions over a range of environmentally relevant geochemical conditions. Metal sorption is being monitored over time, and operative mechanisms are determined using synchrotron-based X-ray absorption spectroscopy. The team studies Fe atom cycling between the aqueous phase and the GR solid with Fe-55 radiotracers, and monitors the structure and morphology of GR using X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy analyses. The research provides educational opportunities and exposure to research to graduate and undergraduate students, including members of underrepresented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project funded by this grant supported research into the reactivity of green rust (GR) minerals. These iron (Fe) phases are prevalent in both engineered and natural reducing environments such as drinking water lines, permeable reactive barriers, river floodplain soils, and aquifers. Because of their layered structure and high content of structural ferrous iron [Fe(II)], GR minerals are highly reactive towards pollutants and nutrients, which they may degrade and/or immobilize through reduction-oxidation (redox) and complexation reactions at their surface. GR therefore plays an important role in regulating water quality in reducing geochemical systems. Mechanistic information on its reactivity is, however, limited, because GR is difficult to study owing to its high sensitivity to oxidation, which causes the mineral to rapidly convert to “regular” rust when exposed to air even briefly. The aim of the current project was to study the mechanisms involved in the immobilization of a series of common heavy metal pollutants, using strict experimental protocols to prevent exposure to air at all times.

The metals selected for this project were divalent manganese [Mn(II)], cobalt [Co(II)], nickel [Ni(II)], zinc [Zn(II)], and cadmium [Cd(II)], which all are redox-stable in the presence of GR and interact with its surface exclusively through sorption reactions. Using a combination laboratory-based batch studies and synchrotron-based X-ray absorption spectroscopic (XAS) analyses, we observed that GR exhibits bimodal sorption behavior: the uptake of Mn(II) and Cd(II) from solution was limited and confined to coordination at surface sites, while sorption of Co(II), Ni(II), and Zn(II) was extensive and involved incorporation of the metals into the GR mineral lattice. The key factor explaining the difference was ionic size: Mn(II) and Cd(II) are both larger than Fe(II) while the other thee metals are smaller. The larger size of Mn(II) and Cd(II) makes them incompatible with the GR structure preventing incorporation, whereas smaller Co(II), Ni(II), and Zn(II) are readily accommodated. These results imply that GR strongly limits the solubility of smaller metal cations in reducing geochemical environments but has very little impact on the retention of larger cations.

The incorporation of Ni(II), Zn(II), and Co(II) into the GR mineral lattice was remarkable in that it implies that GR is a dynamic sorbent that undergoes extensive dissolution and reprecipitation reactions leading to mineral recrystallization. To further study this, we used scanning transmission electron microscopy coupled with electron dispersive (STEM-EDX) to study the nano-scale distribution of sorbed Ni(II) in GR platelets, and conducted radiotracer experiments with Fe-55 radio-isotopes to study the cycling of Fe atoms between solution and the mineral solid. The STEM-EDX results showed that Ni(II) accumulated in ~10 nm rims along GR particle edges during the first hours and days of sorption, but appeared to migrate into the bulk during subsequent months. These results are consistent with the dynamic recrystallization of GR, and suggest that the retention of Ni(II) (and other compatible cations) by GR will become more effective and stable with time. The Fe-55 results are similarly consistent with a dynamic surface, demonstrating Fe atom transfer between the GR crystal lattice and aqueous phase. This behavior is attributed to interfacial redox reactions between dissolved ferrous Fe [Fe(II)] and structural ferric Fe [Fe(III)] driving atom exchange.

Further mechanistic insights were gained from sorption experiments conducted with the mineral nikischerite, which has the same structure as GR but contains structural aluminum [Al(III)] instead of Fe(III). Because Al(III) does not exchange electrons with Fe(II), nikischerite will not undergo recrystallization through interfacial redox reactions. Comparison of the sorption behaviors of nikischerite and GR indicated that the incorporation of small metals is not solely due to mineral recrystallization driven by interfacial redox processes, but also occurs through differences in solubility between the initial and final mineral phases.

The project has provided new mechanistic information on how GR immobilizes metal pollutants. These new insights will help improve geochemical models of the mobility and toxicity of metals in reducing soils, sediments, aquifers, and in water distribution and treatment systems. The findings have been published in peer-reviewed journals and presented at professional meetings. The project promoted the training of a new generation of scientist by supporting the research and professional development of a PhD graduate student and a postdoctoral research associate at Rutgers-Newark, and by involving 6 undergraduate researchers. Five undergraduate students participated through the NSF-funded Dynamic Urban Environmental Systems and Sustainability - Research Experiences for Undergraduates (DUESS-REU) program based at Rutgers-Newark. The students conducted research on GR in the PI’s laboratory for 8 weeks during the Summers of 2021, 2022, and 2023. One undergraduate student participated through the Garden State Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (GS-LSAMP) program at Rutgers-Newark, conducting metal sorption experiments with GR.
